metadata.case_name: Assessee Firm v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The appellant is a firm doing the business of importing dates from abroad and selling them in India.
The appeal relates to the assessment year 1949-50, the accounting year ended on July 25, 1948.
During the accounting year the appellant imported dates from Iraq.
At the relevant time the import of dates by steamers was prohibited by notifications dated December 12, 1946, and June 4, 1947, but permitted by country craft.
Goods ordered by the appellant were received partly by steamer and partly by country craft.
Consignments imported by steamer valued at Rs. 5 lacs were confiscated by Customs Authorities under s. 167, item 8 of the Sea Customs Act.
Under s. 183 of the Sea Customs Act, the appellant was given option to pay fines aggregating Rs. 1,63,950 which on appeal was reduced to Rs. 82,250.
Rs. 82,250 was paid and the dates were released.
On the sale of the goods certain profits accrued out of which the appellant sought to deduct Rs. 82,250 paid as penalty on ordinary principles of commercial accounting.
The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim.
The Appellate Assistant Commissioner also disallowed the claim.
On appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, the sum was held allowable by majority of two to one.
At the instance of the respondent, the Tribunal referred the question to the High Court.
High Court of Bombay by judgment dated February 25, 1955 answered the question against the assessee.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the payment of Rs. 82,250 is an allowable expenditure under Section 10(2)(xv) of the Indian Income-tax Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: The payment was not a penalty but for salvaging the goods; confiscation is proceeding in rem, not personal penalty.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Maqbool Hussain v. State of Bombay; Shewpujanrai Indrasanrai Ltd. v. Collector of Customs; Leo Roy Frey v. Superintendent; Thomas Dana v. State of Punjab

petitioner_arguments.text: It is a commercial loss within contemplation of business.

respondent_arguments.text: The amount could not be said to have been paid for salvaging the goods but was paid as a penalty incurred in consequence of an illegal act on the part of the appellant.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 10(2)(xv) Income-tax Act; Sea Customs Act s.167(8)

court_reasoning.text: Penalty paid for infraction of law is not allowable as deduction under s.10(2)(xv) as it is not wholly and exclusively laid out for purpose of business; it is not a commercial loss but imposed for breach of law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Infraction of law is not normal incident of business; penalties fall on assessee in character other than trader.

court_reasoning.text: Distinction between proceeding in rem (confiscation) and in personam irrelevant for deductibility; payment is still penalty for illegal import.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Public policy prevents treating penalty for breach of law as commercial expense.

court_reasoning.text: Reviews English cases: penalties/fines for breach of law not deductible as not 'for the purpose of the trade' but personal penalties.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Expenditure must be to earn profits, not merely connected with trade.

court_reasoning.text: Indian cases confirm: penalties for infraction not deductible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Must be commercial loss contemplatable in trade.

holdings.text: Payment of penalty under Sea Customs Act for illegal importation is not an allowable deduction under Section 10(2)(xv) of Income-tax Act as it is not expenditure wholly and exclusively for purpose of business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Maqbool Hussain v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Confiscation is proceeding in rem; option to pay fine in lieu.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shewpujanrai Indrasanrai Ltd. v. Collector of Customs
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between in rem and in personam; confiscation against goods.

precedents_cited.case_name: Leo Roy Frey v. Superintendent, District Jail, Amritsar
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar to Maqbool Hussain on customs proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thomas Dana v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Confiscation in rem vs penalty in personam.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Warnes & Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Penalty for breach not commercial loss deductible.
Losses must be wholly for purpose of trade.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Alexander von Glehn & Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Penalty for law infraction not deductible.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mask & Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Damages for dishonest breach not deductible.

precedents_cited.case_name: Senthikumara Nadar & Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Penalty for law infraction not deductible.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Provision for allowable expenditure wholly and exclusively for business purpose; penalty held not allowable.

statutes_cited.name: Sea Customs Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Confiscation for prohibited import; option to pay penalty in lieu.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the Bombay High Court's view that the Rs. 82,250 paid as penalty for illegal importation of dates by steamer is not an allowable deduction under Section 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act, as it is a penalty for infraction of law and not a commercial expense wholly for business purpose.

key_quotes.text: "a penal liability of this kind cannot be regarded as a loss connected with or arising out of a trade... it must... amount to something in the nature of a loss which is contemplable and in the nature of a commercial loss."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines test for deductibility from Warnes case.

key_quotes.text: "Infraction of the law is not a normal incident of business and therefore only such disbursements can be deducted as are really incidental to the business itself."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding why penalty not deductible.

key_quotes.text: "no expense which is paid by way of penalty for a breach of the law can be said to be an amount wholly and exclusively laid for the purpose of the business."
key_quotes.speaker: court
